name: TextDirection
comment:
Bidi stands for Bi-directional text. According to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bi-directional_text: Bi-directional text is text containing text in both text directionalities, both right-to-left (RTL) and left-to-right (LTR). It generally involves text containing different types of alphabets, but may also refer to boustrophedon, which is changing text directionality in each row.

This file provides some utility classes for determining directionality of text, switching CSS layout from LTR to RTL, and other normalizing utilities needed when switching between RTL and LTR formatting.

It defines the TextDirection class which is used to represent directionality of text, In most cases, it is preferable to use bidiformatter.dart, which provides bidi functionality in the given directional context, instead of using bidiutils.dart directly.

value.name: value
value.comment: Textual representation of the directionality constant. One of 'LTR', 'RTL', or 'UNKNOWN'.

spanText.name: spanText
spanText.comment: Textual representation of the directionality when used in span tag.

isDirectionChange.name: isDirectionChange
isDirectionChange.comment: Returns true if intl/intl.TextDirection.isDirectionChange.otherDirection is known to be different from this direction.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides intl/intl.TextDirection.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and intl/intl.TextDirection.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the intl/intl.TextDirection.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
intl/intl.TextDirection.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to intl/intl.TextDirection.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If intl/intl.TextDirection.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of intl/intl.TextDirection.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
